Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

div1.p: No. 44
Consulate General of the U.S. Monrovia Dec. 31, 1886
Mr. S. S. Sevier-
To the Secty of State.
Subject
Returns for a quarter ending Dec. 31, 1886, also yearly returns.
Sir: I have the honor to transmit herewith returns of this Consulate General for the guarter ending Dec. 31, 1886. You will note that my Abstract of Contingent Expreses is very large; that this is
is owing to the great amount of afects of the widow of the late Minister Moses A. Hopkins I had to ship back to her home in N. C.

at the Consulate (8); List of despatches sent to the Department of State (9); Aggregate return of fees at this Consulate for the year (10); Agricultural and Commercial report of Liberian producers (11).
I hope these returns will receive the approval of the Department of State.
I am Sir your obedient Servant
Samuel S. Sevier Acting U.S. Consul Gen.
Inclosures
1. Departure and Arrival of American vessels: 2 Summary of business of the Consulate

3. Treasury Fees 4. Abstract of Contingent Expenses. 5. Statement of account. 6. Statement of account for official Cablegram. 7. Names of persons at the Consulate. 8. Despatches sent to Department. 9. Aggregate returns of fees 10. Aggricultural and Commercial report. 11. Digest of Invoice Book.
Liberian Commerce and Agriculture.

The commerce of the country during the year was much impaired by the recent depression in trade. The palmoil, pam kernals, coffee, and ginger, having fallen below their market values; have discouraged the Natives to such an extent, that they refuse to make the palm oil, palm Kernals, and plant their ginger crop. The Americo-Siberian Farmers -the greater bulk- have neglected to clean their coffee plantations; and gather their coffee crop. The nominal sum of twenty five cents per gallon, for palm oil in trade goods, which is equivalent to

twelve cents per gallon United States currency. Palm Kernals Eighty cents per bushel, which is equivalent to FOrty cents per bushel United States currency. Coffee and ginger ten cents per pound which is also equivalent to five cents United States currency. All tend to discourage the makers and producers. The refusal of the Natives and Americo-Siberians, to make, and, gather, these important articles of commerce, of which there are no other substitutes for their deficiencies, has caused a considerable decrease, in the commerce of the country. Tjere was a considerable quantity of American provisions and dry goods shiped via

Hamburg to Siberia in German steamers by American agencies in Hamburg and in return the palm oil, and palm Kernals were shipped to Hamburg sold and proceeds shipped to the United States; but owing to the depression of trade, there has been quite a decrease in this Americo-German trade with Siberia. There is a great demand for American goods in Liberia, and her interior settlements, but owing to the lack of steam communication between the United States and Liberia; and the lack of a demand in the United States, for the raw products of Liberia, Liberian merchants are compelled to carry on the greatest

bulk of their trade, with the English manufacturers of Manchester, and Liverpool. There is likely to be a further decrease, in the price of coffee, the coming season. The English market where the greatest bulk of Siberian coffee is shipped, is being flooded with a great quantity, Brazilian, Java, & Venezuelian coffee, which, in size, strength, or flavor, but in curing. The Liberian Farmers not taking the necessary care in curing their coffee for the market whichcauses the coffee to be depreciated in value. This is also the case with the ginger, which is not allowed the necessary time for drying, hence when
packed, shipped, and sold is inferior to the ginger of other countries.
Agriculture.

This important branch of industry, has taken a sudden vise during the year; Owing I suppase to the depression of trade. The people-especially the heathen Liberians- have seen fit to employ themselves in this branch of industry. Throughout the county of Montserrado, which is the largest county in Siberia, can be seen hundreds of acres, of rice, and corn and numerous other tropical vegetables, under cultivation.

So numerous were these articles of home consumption that they were offered at the capital Monrovia - for trade goods- from pots, tobacco, brass kettles, powder, zuns & Gin which were never sold before but for United States Green backs or coins, English, Dutch, & German Gold, and Siberian Coppers, Many of these tropical vegetables could become important articles of commerce, especially the cassada which makes a starch much superior arrowroot. There is also a great abundance of arrowroot which grows wild could be cultivated and made an important article of

commerce. There are much wealth, and treasures, hidden and undeveloped, in Siberia; which American Capitalists, Manufacturers, Agriculturalists, and Mineralogists, could utilise for their benefit; and increase American commerce. There is no reason why they United States could not control the great bulk of Liberian trade. If Americans would exert themselves in this direction there would be much gain to us. The people- Americo-Liberians and Heathen Liberians, all prefer American goods and would far rather exchange with the Americans than with those they do.
United States Consulate General Monrovia Dec. 1886
